NAEB HEADQUARTERS
1346 Connecticut Avenue, N.W,
Washington 6, D.C.
MEMORANDUM
TO: NAEB Board of Directors
FROM: Harold E. Hill
DATE: April 22, 1963
I am enclosing a copy of an analysis we have just made of educational
stations in the United States.
I believe you will be as concerned as we are over the decline in percentage
of educational FM and TV stations belonging to the NAEB. Below is a table
showing comparative figures for such studies made approximately a year
apart over the past three years. The first figure in the series of three
for each report represents the total number of such educational stations,
the second number indicates the number belonging to the NAEB, and the third
figure represents the percentage of stations which were members.
1/1/60 4/1/61 2/1/62 4/15/63
TV stations 45-37-82.2% 56-50-92.5? 62-54-87? 78-63-80.8%
FM stations 177-129-72.8% 209-143-68.4% 216-150-69.4? 234-159-67.9?
You will notice that the percentage of stations belonging to the Association
has declined. Put another way:
Since January 1, I960, the number of educational FM stations has increased
32.2$, while the number of FM stations belonging to the NAEB has increased
only 23.3%.
During the same period the number of ETV stations has climbed 73.3%, while
the number of members has increased only 70.3%. And, even more graphically,
during the past two years (since April 1, 1961), while the number of ETV
stations increased 39.3%, our membership increased only 26%.
Since it is impossible for the staff to do much nevangelistic‚Äù work in the
field, it is hoped that the members of the Board will increase their efforts
to bring into membership those non-members in their respective Regions.
The non-member ETV stations are listed on the attached analysis, and I am
also enclosing a list of non-member radio stations for your use.
The number of AM stations has remained static for several years, with the
exception of W1NAD, University of Oklahoma, which "went commercial" about
a year ago. You will notice, furthermore, that most of the non-member AM
stations are owned and operated by churches or church-connected groups.
